body: -1 on this. i would rather leave the numpy things isolated in a single place. you can certainly typedef things to use the same structure, though as this didn't appear to actually change anything in setup.py I am not sure this changes anything.

> though as this didn't appear to actually change anything in setup.py I am not sure this changes anything

Correct.  As mentioned, this PR is just the search+replace, does not implement the mentioned upsides.

> i would rather leave the numpy things isolated in a single place.

That's a reasonable preference.  The two big motivations I have in mind are:

- In trying to get `cythonize` working, the src directory is a PITA.  Having fewer things depend on it will make life better.

- I'm pretty sure that 'source'/'include'/'pxdfiles' keys affect build time.  I'll try to do some profiling and check this.  If that turns out to be wrong, I'll drop this.

> you can certainly typedef things to use the same structure

I poked at this but without much luck.  Is there a way to do this such that I could import npy_datetimestruct in a cython file and use it interchangeably with pandas_datetimestruct?  Or heck, import it `as pandas_datetimestruct`?  That would be just as effective as the changes in this PR, but with a much smaller footprint.

Got some profiling info on the build.  Let me know if there's a more appropriate place for this since its part of a larger issue.

Ran `python setup.py clean` followed by `python setup.py build_ext --inplace` N times, timed the latter.

A) Under master (as of yesterday morning):
N = 59
mean = 307.963 seconds
stdev  = 2.155 seconds

B) Branch in which I removed all the unnecessarily-specified files from `ext_data` in setup.py:
N = 59
mean = 305.954 seconds
stdev = 2.699 seconds

C) Branch in which I _added_ a bunch of unnecessary junk to `ext_data` in setup.py:
N = 10
mean = 323.757 seconds
stdev = 2.103 seconds

2 seconds cut between A and B isn't that big a deal (note `t=4.47`), but there wasn't much cruft to cut in the first place.  Trial C intended as a proxy for what might be available if dependencies were trimmed more thoroughly.  5% isn't world-breaking, but nothing to scoff at.
I am not enthused by this PR. other things to worry about, if in the future you want to come back to this, let's discuss in an issue.
